Desulfovibrio gilichinskyi is a species of sulfate-reducing bacteria that was first isolated from permafrost samples collected in Russia. It is a Gram-negative, curved or spiral-shaped, motile bacterium that belongs to the genus Desulfovibrio within the phylum Proteobacteria.

The key features of Desulfovibrio gilichinskyi are:

1. Metabolism: It is an anaerobic, chemoheterotrophic bacterium that can use a variety of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources. It has the ability to reduce sulfate to sulfide, which is a characteristic of the genus Desulfovibrio.

2. Morphology: Cells are curved or spiral-shaped, approximately 1-3 μm in length and 0.4-0.7 μm in width. They possess a single polar flagellum, which enables their motility.

3. Habitat and Ecology: Desulfovibrio gilichinskyi was originally isolated from permafrost samples, indicating its ability to survive and thrive in cold, oligotrophic environments. It is believed to play a role in the sulfur cycle and the degradation of organic matter in these types of habitats.

4. Genome and Phylogeny: The genome of Desulfovibrio gilichinskyi has been sequenced, providing insights into its genetic makeup and evolutionary relationships. Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that it is closely related to other Desulfovibrio species.

Overall, Desulfovibrio gilichinskyi is a unique and interesting sulfate-reducing bacterium that has adapted to the challenging conditions of permafrost environments and contributes to the cycling of sulfur and organic matter in these ecosystems.
